polylogic.org.protocols.ModBus

Class ModBus

  • java.lang.Object
    • polylogic.org.protocols.ModBus.ModBus

  • public class ModBus
extends Object
    This library generates typical requests for Modbus protocol. Currently Modbus RTU, Modbus TCP(UDP), Modbus over TCP(UDP) and Modbus ASCII are supported. CRC and LRC calculators and checkers are also implemented. Console (CLI) version is provided as example of library usage. Additionally library can apply or check CRC (CRC-16-ANSI for now, LRC CRC will be added soon) for both Modbus requests and replies. Modbus is a serial communications protocol originally published by Modicon (now Schneider Electric) in 1979 for use with its programmable logic controllers (PLCs). Simple and robust, it has since become a de facto standard communication protocol, and it is now a commonly available means of connecting industrial electronic devices. Modbus organization web site: http://www.modbus.org/ Basic modbus reference can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modbus Note that this library is not strict to Modbus standard implementation because, unfortunately, some manufacturers implement addressing in non-standard way, like using 40000 holding register address, 248-255 device addresses and so on, so this library won't check whether device, coil, register etc addresses comply to generic Modbus standard, but will allow any reasonable values as input parameters to allow non-standard implementations work. All offsets of registers addresses must be applied before functions calls, they are described in functions descriptions and Modbus reference manuals.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Stanislav Orlov www.polylogic.org orlovsn@live.ru

      Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP Type (TCP and UDP use the same ADU) without CRC in request and without REQUEST LENGTH field in functions, that have fixed-length answer.

      Read values of holding registers (Modbus function code: 3) Note that holding register address is passed with offset of 40001 - so to point to holding register 40003 you need to point to address 40003-40001=2 To point to 40001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

      Read inputs values (Modbus function code: 2) Note that input address is passed with offset of 10001 - so to point to input 10003 you need to point to address 10003-10001=2 To point to 10001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

    • Field Detail

      • tcpID

        public static int tcpID
        Basically this library carries one identificator and increases it with every call to convertToTCP (internally called in every command generator, when Modbus type is set to Modbus-TCP/UDP). So if you have multiple Modbus-TCP/UDP devices, they will share this id (for example if you have 3 devices, that are requested in order, then first packet to device1 will have id 1, packet to device2 will have id 2, packet to device3 will have id 3). In most cases this works ok because device, due to Modbus standard, don't perfom id check and only copies it in reply, but if you want separate ids for each device, you have to implement your own list of device addresses and take care of exact id increment every time you prepare a command for device, then you can force id with setTcpID function (note that tcpID is static, so if you have multiple threads you have to synchronize your double-call transaction - first set id, than generate command) or you can simply overwrite id with your own in generated command.

      • TYPE_MODBUS_RTU

        public static final int TYPE_MODBUS_RTU
        Modbus RTU Type with CRC-16-ANSI
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP

        public static final int TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP
        Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP Type (TCP and UDP use the same ADU) without CRC in request. Don't mess with Modbus over TCP which requires CRC! This type handles MBAP+PDU, where MBAP Unit Identifier is set as deviceAddress. IMPORTANT MODBUS MESSAGING ON TCP/IP IMPLEMENTATION GUIDE V1.0b says that: "All MODBUS requests and responses are designed in such a way that the recipient can verify that a message is finished. For function codes where the MODBUS PDU has a fixed length, the function code alone is sufficient. For function codes carrying a variable amount of data in the request or response, the data field includes a byte count." When setting TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP type, all generated functions WILL contain length (because most devices will fail if basic MBAP is ruined). If your device fails with byte count in MBAP for fixed-length commands, then use TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP_NO_FIXED_LENGTHS type.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TYPE_MODBUS_OVER_TCP

        public static final int TYPE_MODBUS_OVER_TCP
        Modbus over TCP or Modbus over UDP Type with CRC-16-ANSI. Don't mess with Modbus TCP which doesn't require CRC!
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TYPE_MODBUS_ASCII

        public static final int TYPE_MODBUS_ASCII
        Modbus ASCII with LRC CRC
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP_NO_FIXED_LENGTHS

        public static final int TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP_NO_FIXED_LENGTHS
        Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP Type (TCP and UDP use the same ADU) without CRC in request and without REQUEST LENGTH field in functions, that have fixed-length answer. IMPORTANT MODBUS MESSAGING ON TCP/IP IMPLEMENTATION GUIDE V1.0b says that: "All MODBUS requests and responses are designed in such a way that the recipient can verify that a message is finished. For function codes where the MODBUS PDU has a fixed length, the function code alone is sufficient. For function codes carrying a variable amount of data in the request or response, the data field includes a byte count." So looks like there are devices (I have never met them, but standard is standard) that may fail if you provide REQUEST LENGTH in request, so you should provide this type of Modbus for command generators in case you have such a device.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RESPONSE_Acknowledge

        public static final int RESPONSE_Acknowledge
        Slave has accepted request and is processing it, but a long duration of time is required. This response is returned to prevent a timeout error from occurring in the master. Master can next issue a Poll Program Complete message to determine if processing is completed
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RESPONSE_Slave_Device_Busy

        public static final int RESPONSE_Slave_Device_Busy
        Slave is engaged in processing a long-duration command. Master should retry later
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RESPONSE_Negative_Acknowledge

        public static final int RESPONSE_Negative_Acknowledge
        Slave cannot perform the programming functions. Master should request diagnostic or error information from slave
        See Also:

      • RESPONSE_Memory_Parity_Error

        public static final int RESPONSE_Memory_Parity_Error
        Slave detected a parity error in memory. Master can retry the request, but service may be required on the slave device
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • readValueOfCoils

        public static byte[] readValueOfCoils(byte deviceAddress,
                                      int firstCoilAddress,
                                      int numberOfCoils,
                                      int modbusType)

        Read coils values (Modbus function code: 1)

        For example to read value of 3 coils starting from coil 2 in device with address 10 in RTU format write: readValueOfCoils(10, 2, 3, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstCoilAddress - First coil address
        numberOfCoils - Number of coils to read
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • readValueOfInputs

        public static byte[] readValueOfInputs(byte deviceAddress,
                                       int firstInputAddress,
                                       int numberOfInputs,
                                       int modbusType)

        Read inputs values (Modbus function code: 2)

        Note that input address is passed with offset of 10001 - so to point to input 10003 you need to point to address 10003-10001=2 To point to 10001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

        For example to read value of 3 inputs starting from input 10002 in device with address 10 in RTU format write: readValueOfInputs(10, 1, 3, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstInputAddress - First coil address
        numberOfInputs - Number of coils to read
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • readValueOfHoldingRegisters

        public static byte[] readValueOfHoldingRegisters(byte deviceAddress,
                                                 int firstRegisterAddress,
                                                 int numberOfRegisters,
                                                 int modbusType)

        Read values of holding registers (Modbus function code: 3)

        Note that holding register address is passed with offset of 40001 - so to point to holding register 40003 you need to point to address 40003-40001=2 To point to 40001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

        For example to read value of 3 holding registers starting from register 40002 in device with address 10 in RTU format write: readValueOfHoldingRegisters(10, 1, 3, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstRegisterAddress - First register address
        numberOfRegisters - Number of registers to read
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • readValueOfInputRegisters

        public static byte[] readValueOfInputRegisters(byte deviceAddress,
                                               int firstRegisterAddress,
                                               int numberOfRegisters,
                                               int modbusType)

        Read values of input registers (Modbus function code: 4)

        Note that input register address is passed with offset of 30001 - so to point to register 30003 you need to point to address 30003-30001=2 To point to 30001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

        For example to read value of 3 input registers starting from register 30002 in device with address 10 in RTU format write: readValueOfInputRegisters(10, 1, 3, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstRegisterAddress - First register address
        numberOfRegisters - Number of registers to read
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • writeValueOfSingleCoil

        public static byte[] writeValueOfSingleCoil(byte deviceAddress,
                                            int coilAddress,
                                            int newCoilValue,
                                            int modbusType)

        Writes value of single coil (Modbus function code: 5)

        For example to write value 70 in coil 2 of device with address 10 in RTU format write: writeValueOfSingleCoil(10, 2, 70, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of Device where command will be executed (slave device)
        coilAddress - Address of Coil where new value should be written to
        newCoilValue - New Coil value. Due to Modbus standard, coil values must be 0 (disable) or 1 (enable), but as we are not strict any value will be accepted but values diffe7++++++++++++
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • writeValueOfSingleHoldingRegister

        public static byte[] writeValueOfSingleHoldingRegister(byte deviceAddress,
                                                       int registerAddress,
                                                       int newRegisterValue,
                                                       int modbusType)

        Writes value of single holding register (Modbus function code: 6)

        Note that holding register address is passed with offset of 40001 - so to point to holding register 40003 you need to point to address 40003-40001=2 To point to 40001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

        For example to write value 70 in holding register 40002 of device with address 10 in RTU format write: writeValueOfSingleHoldingRegister(10, 1, 70, TYPE_MODBUS_RTU);

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of Device where command will be executed (slave device)
        registerAddress - Address of Register where new value should be written to
        newRegisterValue - New Register value
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • writeValueOfMultipleHoldingRegisters

        public static byte[] writeValueOfMultipleHoldingRegisters(byte deviceAddress,
                                                          int firstRegisterAddress,
                                                          List<Integer> newRegistersValues,
                                                          int modbusType)

        Writes values of multiple holding registers (Modbus function code: 16)

        Note that holding register address is passed with offset of 40001 - so to point to holding register 40003 you need to point to address 40003-40001=2 To point to 40001 address you need to point to 0 address (zero offset).

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of Device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstRegisterAddress - Address of first Register where new values should be written to
        newRegistersValues - List of new Registers values. Number of registers to write data to will be calculated from this List's size.
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • writeValueOfMultipleCoils

        public static byte[] writeValueOfMultipleCoils(byte deviceAddress,
                                               int firstCoilAddress,
                                               List<Integer> newCoilsValues,
                                               int modbusType)

        Writes values of multiple coils (Modbus function code: 15)

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of Device where command will be executed (slave device)
        firstCoilAddress - Address of first Coil where new values should be written to
        newCoilsValues - List of new Coils values. Any int above 0 will be parsed as 1 (enable), 0 or negative ints will be parsed as 0 (disable). Number of coils to write data to will be calculated from this List's size.
        modbusType - Defines output data format. Currently only RTU, TCP/UDP and over TCP/UDP types implemented.
        If RTU or Modbus over TCP is selected output will be binary with CRC-16-ANSI.
        If TCP (for UDP use TCP mode - they are the same) is selected output will be binary without TCP, ASCII will return byte-formated ASCII with LRC CRC.
        Note that Modbus over TCP/IP and Modbus TCP are different - don't mess them! Modbus TCP relies on TCP's correction mechanisms and don't use CRC in Modbus commands - some devices operating Modbus TCP or Modbus UDP will fail to communicate with CRC applied.
        Returns:
        Prepared to execute command.

      • prepareRTU6ByteCommand

        public static byte[] prepareRTU6ByteCommand(byte deviceAddress,
                                            byte command,
                                            int address,
                                            int value)

        Creates skeleton of simple 6-byte Modbus RTU command

        For example to read value of 3 coils starting from coil 2 in device with address 10 write: prepareRTU6ByteCommand(10,1,2,3); where 1 is read coil status modbus command

        Parameters:
        deviceAddress - Address of device where command will be executed (slave device)
        command - Modbus command number (see Modbus reference)
        address - First command argument, usually address of register or coil
        value - Second command argument, usually number of registers or coils
        Returns:
        Skeleton of command with filled arguments without CRC (Address + PDU block)

      • applyCRC

        public static byte[] applyCRC(byte[] preparedCommand)

        Applies CRC-16-ANSI to given command

        Command must contain PDU (function code and function value) and device address

        Parameters:
        preparedCommand - device address and PDU
        Returns:
        byte[] command with CRC-16-ANSI applied in last two bytes.

      • applyLRC

        public static byte[] applyLRC(byte[] preparedCommand)

        Applies ASCII LRC to given command

        Command must contain PDU (function code and function value) and device address

        Parameters:
        preparedCommand - device address and PDU
        Returns:
        byte[] command with ASCII LRC applied in last byte.

      • checkReply

        public static int checkReply(byte[] reply,
                             int modbusType)
        Checks provided device reply for errors: overall validity, exception codes and CRC/LRC errors
        Parameters:
        reply - whole reply from device
        modbusType - defines Modbus ADU type, device is operating on.
        Returns:
        0 if no errors where found, or error response code.

      • checkCRC

        public static boolean checkCRC(byte[] reply)
        Checks whether provided reply has valid length and contains valid CRC
        Parameters:
        reply - device reply to check
        Returns:
        true if CRC is valid, false if CRC is not valid

      • checkLRC

        public static boolean checkLRC(byte[] reply)
        Checks whether provided ASCII reply contains valid LRC
        Parameters:
        reply - device reply to check
        Returns:
        true if LRC is valid, false if LRC is not valid

      • convertToASCII

        public static byte[] convertToASCII(byte[] preparedCommand)

        Converts given command to ModBus ASCII format

        Command must contain PDU (function code and function value) and device address

        Parameters:
        preparedCommand - device address and PDU
        Returns:
        byte[] ModBus ASCII command.

      • convertToTCP

        public static byte[] convertToTCP(byte[] preparedCommand)
        Adds MBAP Header to provided prepared command. Unit Identifier is taken from deviceAddress field of command. Note that this function allways sets CONTENT LENGTH field in MBAP. If you don't need this field for fixed-length commands, then use convertToTCPNoFixedLength instead. For more information see descriptions of TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP and TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP_NO_FIXED_LENGTHS
        Parameters:
        preparedCommand - command to add MBAP to
        Returns:
        MBAP header + command

      • convertToTCPNoFixedLength

        public static byte[] convertToTCPNoFixedLength(byte[] preparedCommand)
        Adds MBAP Header to provided prepared command. Unit Identifier is taken from deviceAddress field of command. Note that this function sets CONTENT LENGTH field in MBAP only for variable-length commands or commands with variable length responses (Actually all but 5 and 6 function codes). If you need this field for every command, then use convertToTCP instead. For more information see descriptions of TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP and TYPE_MODBUS_TCP_UDP_NO_FIXED_LENGTHS
        Parameters:
        preparedCommand - command to add MBAP to
        Returns:
        MBAP header + command

      • stripReplyToDATA

        public static byte[] stripReplyToDATA(byte[] reply,
                                      int typeModbus)
        Strips device reply to data only, removing device address, function code, CRC and TCP/UDP or ASCII overhead. NOTE Null will be returned if there was an error code or reply was too short.
        Parameters:
        reply - Full reply from device
        typeModbus - Type of Modbus ADU
        Returns:
        Only data (without device address, function code, CRC and TCP/UDP or ASCII overhead) OR null if there was an error code or reply was too short

      • stripReplyToPDU

        public static byte[] stripReplyToPDU(byte[] reply,
                                     int typeModbus)
        Strips device reply to address + PDU, removing CRC and TCP/UDP or ASCII overhead.
        Parameters:
        reply - Full reply from device
        typeModbus - Type of Modbus ADU
        Returns:
        address + PDU without CRC and TCP/UDP or ASCII overhead.

      • getTcpID

        public static int getTcpID()
        Returns:
        Current Identification of a MODBUS Request transaction.

      • setTcpID

        public static void setTcpID(int tcpID)
        Basically this library carries one identificator and increases it with every call to convertToTCP (internally called in every command generator, when Modbus type is set to Modbus-TCP/UDP). So if you have multiple Modbus-TCP/UDP devices, they will share this id (for example if you have 3 devices, that are requested in order, then first packet to device1 will have id 1, packet to device2 will have id 2, packet to device3 will have id 3). In most cases this works ok because device, due to Modbus standard, don't perfom id check and only copies it in reply, but if you want separate ids for each device, you have to implement your own list of device addresses and take care of exact id increment every time you prepare a command for device, then you can force id with this function (note that it is static, so if you have multiple threads you have to synchronize your double-call transaction - first set id, than generate command) or you can simply overwrite id with your own in generated command.
        Parameters:
        tcpID - New Identification of a MODBUS Request transaction for next generated command.

      • convertCommandToModbusType

        public static byte[] convertCommandToModbusType(byte[] command,
                                                int modbusType)

        public static void main(String[] args)
